topic.title: Adding Custom HTML Content in WebHelp Responsive Output

keywords.indexterm: WebHelp Responsive systemAdd custom HTML content

body.p: You can add custom HTML content in the WebHelp Responsive output by inserting it in a well-formed XML file that will be referenced in the transformation scenario. This content may include references to additional JavaScript, CSS, and other types of resources, or such resources can be inserted inline within the HTML content that is inserted in the XML file.
There are several things to consider in regards to this XML file:

section.title: Using Oxygen XML Editor/Author
section.p:
To include custom HTML content in the WebHelp Responsive output files using a transformation scenario from within Oxygen XML Editor/Author, follow this procedure:
Insert the HTML content in a well-formed XML file (see comments above).
Edit the WebHelp Responsive transformation scenario.
Go to the Parameters tab.
Edit the value of the webhelp.fragment.head parameter and set it to the absolute path of the XML file created in step 1.
Click OK to save the changes to the transformation scenario.
Result: Your additional content will be included at the end of the head element of your output document.If you want to insert the content in another location within the output document, you can reference the XML file from any other HTML Fragment extension points.

section.title: Using a Script Outside of Oxygen XML Editor/Author

note.product: author developer editor authorEclipse developerEclipse editorEclipse

section.p:
To include custom HTML content in the WebHelp Responsive output files using a script outside of Oxygen XML Editor/Author, follow this procedure:
Insert the HTML content in a well-formed XML file (see comments above).
Specify the absolute path to that XML file using the webhelp.fragment.head parameter.
Execute the transformation script.
Result: Your additional content will be included at the end of the head element of your output document.If you want to insert the content in another location within the output document, you can reference the XML file from any other HTML Fragment extension points.

For example:
Windows:
dita.bat -i c:\mySample.ditamap -f webhelp-responsive -Dwebhelp.fragment.head=c:\myFile.xml
Mac OS X/ Linux:
dita -i C:/mySample.ditamap -f webhelp-responsive -Dwebhelp.fragment.head=C:/myFile.xml
